p: The genus Amaranthus comprises over 40 species ( Sauer 1957), including crops grown for grains and vegetables ( Joshi et al. 2018), as well as many invasive weeds of agricultural and natural systems (e.g., Rowland, Murray, and Verhalen 1999; Bensch, Horak, and Peterson 2003). Most Amaranthus species are monoecious, while a few species exhibit a dioecious breeding system. In early classifications, dioecious Amaranthus species were grouped into a single subgenus ( Acnida) based on their reproductive system ( Mosyakin and Robertson 1996). Genome-wide phylogenetic work, however, indicated that these species cluster with monoecious species in distinct clades ( Stetter and Schmid 2017). Hence, dioecy probably evolved multiple times independently within the Amaranthus genus.
